page.lettertext:
fol.219r
Belgia 1594 21 July
Maye it please your good L. Assoone as I had sealed my former unto yow
upon a new advertisement sent hither from
M
r
Caron
to
e
States,
there
were certaine deputed to conferre agayne with me, and to learne what
I could signifie, as touching those dmaundes, which were made by her
Ma
tie
and proposed to M
r
Caron
e 15 of this mo
n
eth in your L:
howse in
London:
But declaring
at I had not understood the particu-
lar pointes, they imparted them unto me, and signified withall
at for
9 or 10 shippes for 3 mo
n
ethes requyred by her Ma
tie
, they did not
thincke
at
e Contrey would make anie difficultie, nor for
e twentie
thowsand weight of powder, but they could not comprehend what
was meant by that point: wherein her Ma
tie
doth desire to be served
of two mo
n
eths victuals for two thowsand men. For they doe
presume,
at all kinde of victuals are more aboundant and better
cheape, and more ready for
at service in
England
then heere; and
that they can not well carry for more then 3 mo
n
eths victuals.
Agayn they seemed to mervayle at if it were intended,
at
e Forte
before
Brest
shold be taken from
e Enemie there was noe mention
of Munition, and
at for powder soe small a quantitie was demaun-
ded: for
at in these Contries they doe make provision at
e least
at
e siege of any place
at is of importance of two hundred thowsand
weight, and of fivetie thowsand only to serve for
e small shotte.
(I could not tell w
at
to aunswear to any of these doubtes, because
I had receaved no c
o
mssion about it, nor was not rashlie to
conjecture at her Ma
ties
meaning. Howbeyt perceaving by their
speeches, that they would not shrincke in anie point, but were rather
inclined to affourd a greater proportion of every thinge demaunded
then was mentioned by her Ma
tie
I sollicited them in
at behalfe,
declaring for
e rest,
t
I thought those demaundes were onely made
by waye of c
o
munication and proceeded of an unperfect project cast
upon
e first meeting onely, and that they should be thoroughlie
satisifed, when I had my letters, which I expected everie howre.
Wher upon they concluded
at for reasons alleaged at
e time of my
Audience (which I have sette downe in my former to your L:)
and because M
r
Caron
e very same daye
at he had speeche with
her Ma
tie
in your L: howse receaved after a l
re
from
S
r
Robert
Cecill
, wherein he was requested in her Hig
es
name to stay
fol.219v
his dispatche, because she had not yet taken a full resolution, they
could not take order upon anie thing required, but presently upon
notice of her determinat finall purpose, with some 16 or 20 day
[es]
warning, they would be ready with their Navie, and all thing
[es]
appertaining.
And thus I take my humble leave
From
e Haghe July 21
1594
.
